item.title: How to SSH Back to Local Machine Via Reverse Shell
item.description: Situation Link to heading Your local machine is connected to the internet via a router that do not have control over. You are able to SSH into your work machine in another building/office without issues (connected via ethernet with static IP etc), but what if you want SSH access back to your local machine while in office? This can be achieved with reverse shell. Configuration Link to heading On the work machine (which acts as the server too): sudoedit /etc/ssh/sshd_config

item.title: Drawing a Circle in SDL3
item.description: Surprisingly, the SDL library does not provide a way to draw a circle natively. Circles are usually drawn with the usage of sdl2-gfx or implementing the midpoint algorithm. At the time of writing (11/05/2024), the sdl2-gfx library isn’t updated to be compatible with SDL3 yet. This example ports the filledCircleRGBA() method manually: https://github.com/jchai01/comp4300-with-sdl/tree/main/a1 Steps Link to heading Search and extract the desired function in the header file SDL2_gfxPrimitives.h Extract the function along with all the other function it depends on from SDL2_gfxPrimitives.

item.title: Format Flashdrive with fdisk
item.description: lsblk to check which drive to format. sudo fdisk -l can be used too for more details. Unmount drive: umount /dev/sdb1 Select the drive, without the number (sdc instead of sdc1): sudo fdisk /dev/sdc g to create new GPT partition n to write new partition press enter to use default value, entire drive w to to write. lsblk again to confirm. Set filesystem type e.g. fat32. Select the partition, this time with the number (sdc1): sudo mkfs.

item.title: Connect to Ethernet with Manual IP in Arch Installation medium
item.description: Arch installation medium uses systemd-networkd Edit the config file: vim /etc/systemd/network/20-ethernet.network Edit the [Network] portion in the file, write Address in CIDR notation. Remove or comment out DHCP related lines. Run systemctl restart systemd-networkd. Example: [Network] Address=143.239.81.132/24 Gateway=143.239.81.254 DNS=143.239.1.2 If the .network config file does not exist (for e.g. outside of the installation medium), create it at /etc/systemd/network/20-ethernet.network Minimally, the whole config file should look something like this: [Match] Name=e* [Network] Address=143.

item.title: nvim.surround overwrite default white space behaviour
item.description: Using ( in nvim.surround surrounds word with white space like so: ( word ). ) have to be used instead. The following changes in the nvim.surround.lua file overwrites this behaviour. return { { "kylechui/nvim-surround", -- tag = "*", -- Use for stability; omit to use `main` branch for the latest features config = function() require("nvim-surround").setup { surrounds = { ["("] = { add = function() return { { "(" }, { ")" } } end, }, ["{"] = { add = function() return { { "{" }, { "}" } } end, }, ["["] = { add = function() return { { "[" }, { "]" } } end, }, ["<"] = { add = function() return { { "<" }, { ">" } } end, }, }, } end, }, }

item.title: Setup SSH in Github
item.description: Create SSH key Link to heading ssh-keygen -o -t rsa -C "any comment" The -o flag forces the tool to generate SSH keys with the OpenSSH format. The -t flag specifies the type of SSH keys to create. The -C flag allows for comments that get added as metadata at the end of the public key. Key generated to ~/.ssh folder View SSH key Link to heading cat ~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub

item.title: Redshift Guide
item.description: Toggle + Location Agnostic Setup Link to heading Create/edit the file ~/.config/redshift/redshift.conf, set temp-day and temp-night to the same value. lat and lon can be set randomly as it doesn’t matter. Example: [redshift] temp-day=3500 temp-night=3500 fade=0 location-provider=manual [manual] lat=48.864716 lon=2.349014 Set startup to run redshift. Enable toggle with pkill -USR1 '^redshift$', bind it to a hotkey. Manual Usage Link to heading With Redshift, you can set brightness level lower than the minumum.

item.title: Why x86 needs to die, summary
item.description: This blog is a compilation of summaries and insights gathered from this video by ThePrimeagen , where he reacts to an article titled “Why x86 needs to die” together with hardware expert Casey Muratori. A counter-article is also available at Chip and Cheese , a site that blogs about micro analysis stuff, and it’s recommended by Casey. Why are register names so weird? (4:35) Link to heading In assembly language, general purpose register names from the second half made sense (named r8, r9, r10, r11 …) but not the first half (they are not named r0, r1, r2 …) because original 8000 series CPUs started out with four registers: A, B, C, and D.

item.title: Right to repair, why you should care?
item.description: E-waste Link to heading Once upon a time, any electronics you bought would come with a schematic documenting their inner workings. Not only are these official schematics almost impossible to obtain due to “trade secrets,” try to disassemble any electronic device, and you will be met with a bunch of roadblocks: excessive use of adhesive, non-modular/soldered parts, and the requirement of proprietary tools. Apple even invented a mechanically inferior screw called the pentalobe screw just to keep people out of their hardware.

item.title: FFMPEG cheatsheet
item.description: Changing Aspect Ratio Link to heading Resizing a video from 4:3 to 16:9 (HD, 1280 x 720) for max screen size, with no cropping and addition of black padding ffmpeg -i input.mp4 -vf "scale=(iw*sar)*min(1280/(iw*sar)\,720/ih):ih*min(1280/(iw*sar)\,720/ih),pad=1280:720:(ow-iw)/2:(oh-ih)/2:black" output.mp4 Explanation: *scale = FFMPEG video filter to resize a video (iw*sar)min(1280/(iwsar),720/ih) = output width of the resized video = Resize width of video to AT MOST 1280 (keeping original aspect ratio) ihmin(1280/(iwsar),720/ih) = output height of the resized video = Resize width of video to AT MOST 720 (keeping original aspect ratio) The scale transformation is then followed (chained) by a pad video filter:

item.title: Setup Latest NeoVim Guide
item.description: Executable Link to heading Download the NeoVim tar file. Rename nvim.appimage to nvim mv nvim.appimage nvim Set the permission: chmod +x nvim Install fuse2 library if it is required to run the appimage sudo apt install libfuse2 Copy from download folder to /usr/local/bin path /usr/bin is used for apps managed by the distribution’s package manager, so it’s not recommended to copy there.
